column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=The rapid development of large-scale pharmaceutical manufacturing has contributed to increased concentrations of contaminants present in wastewater and surface waters .

#Text=Pharmaceutical wastewaters are produced during the drug manufacturing processes ( i. e. , fermentation , extraction , chemical synthesis , formulation , packaging and washing of solid cake and equipment ) .
#Text=Hence , the main pollution source of these pharmaceutical compounds in the environment is through industrial process water discharge .
#Text=Several studies have shown that pharmaceutical drugs ( and their derived metabolites ) are found in effluents of wastewater treatment plants ( WWTPs ) and their removal is very inefficient .
#Text=Wastewater originating during the manufacturing of antidiabetic drugs is also an important environmental challenge due to the high production volume .

#Text=Several research papers have reported the occurrence , degradability , and environmental impact of antidiabetic drugs in wastewater , and substantial efforts to achieve environmental improvements in line with regulations and legislation have been implemented .
#Text=Metformin ( C4H11N5 ) is one of the most prescribed and widely used antidiabetic drugs worldwide , since a significant portion of the population suffers from diabetes .
#Text=Recent reports have indicated that there are also high concentrations of metformin in domestic wastewater treatment plants ’ influent .
#Text=This is because it is excreted un-metabolized from the human body in urine and ends up in wastewater and aquatic environments .
#Text=Metformin is the pharmaceutical compound with the highest concentration in domestic wastewater ( i. e. , 64 – 98 µg/L ) .
#Text=This study is therefore relevant for wastewater treatment in general , even though it is focused on metformin-containing industrial wastewater .
#Text=Pharmaceutical wastewater has traditionally been treated using conventional physico-chemical and biological process methods .
#Text=Metformin can be aerobically degraded to guanylurea ( C2H6N4O ) — a metabolite that is stable against further biodegradation in wastewater treatment plants .
#Text=However , it appears to be a novel idea to integrate anaerobic and aerobic processes for the efficient removal of metformin and other pharmaceutical constituents .
#Text=The basic hypothesis of this study is that anaerobic granular sludge and aerobic biofilms supported by a hybrid vertical anaerobic biofilm ( HyVAB® ) reactor design (
#Text=Figure 1

#Text=) are the most robust combined niches for microorganisms to treat inhibitory substances , since microbial aggregates protect the microorganisms against such substances as they are delivered slowly by diffusion from the liquid phase .
#Text=The more sensitive organisms are in the deeper layers protected by layers of organisms embedded in an extracellular polymeric matrix .
#Text=Adaptation to toxic chemicals can be slow and can go through the stages of survival , tolerance , capture , and — if at all biodegradable — the final adaptation stage is degradation .
#Text=The process can even remove non-biodegradable constituents by integration in the extracellular matrix to build more aggregates .
#Text=HyVAB® is a compact reactor that integrates both anaerobic and aerobic processes .
#Text=Wastewater is introduced at the bottom anaerobic digestion ( AD ) stage , where organic matter is degraded and converted into methane .
#Text=The remaining unconsumed organics flow up for further treatment in the aerobic biofilm stage designed as a Continuous Flow Intermittent Cleaning ( CFIC® ) .
#Text=Plastic bio-carriers serve as a biofilm substratum in the aerobic biofilm stage , protecting the biofilm from shear force .
#Text=Excess aerobic sludge is washed off during the intermittent washing process ( i. e. , CFIC® ) .
#Text=Part of the detached aerobic biofilm settles down by gravity to the AD stage in the HyVAB® , where it is degraded simultaneously with the feed substrates .

#Text=In this study , two types of wastewater — wastewater I ( WWI ) and wastewater II ( WWII ) — were fed to the reactor , and performance was evaluated on the basis of metformin reduction , chemical oxygen demand ( COD ) removal efficiency , and biogas production .
